id_1233.author: id_5686
id_1233.title: Read ME!
id_1233.short_text: This is the How this crap work? article, this explain how to use this page, so please read it, else maybe you don't know how to check several feature.
id_1233.full_text:
Hello, this page is full front-end page, so please remember to this when you refresh the page.
Why?
- because we don't save data to database, only into JavaScript objct, but if you refresh the page then every changes will dissapear, also i use a .json file for predefined articles, comments and for users

Please use the this link if you can go to control panel:
Dashboard

Few additional information user for login test:
username: pista, password: 123456
username: ionut, password: abcdef
username: steve87, password: byTheWay
id_1233.html:
Front end page?

Why not? of course this isn't for real useage, but for fun and demonstration it is a interesting option, what do you think?

Basic information

This is the index.html, we have article.html what show to us the whole article and article id is stored in query string and option for article comments and we have a dashboard.html where we can create, update, delete the articles (huhu, just like a CRUD? well just this isn't with ORM hehe).

Account information

Few additional information user for login test:
username: pista, password: 123456
username: ionut, password: abcdef
username: steve87, password: byTheWay

id_1234.author: id_5687
id_1234.title: The wild zebra
id_1234.short_text: Black & white stripes, four legg, who is he? The unique stripes of zebras make them one of the animals most familiar to people.
id_1234.full_text: The name zebra in English dates back to c. 1600, from Italian zebra, perhaps from Portuguese, which in turn is said to be Congolese (as stated in the Oxford English Dictionary). The Encarta Dictionary says its ultimate origin is uncertain, but perhaps it may come from Latin equiferus meaning wild horse; from equus (horse) and ferus (wild, untamed). The word was traditionally pronounced with a long initial vowel, but over the course of the 20th century, the pronunciation with the short initial vowel became the usual one in the UK and Commonwealth. The pronunciation with a long initial vowel remains standard in the United States.
